												I'm going to come back here and update this review. A lot has changed relatively fast, as it typically is in MMOs, so I feel like my old review is a little inaccurate. My first review of this game was posted slightly after 4th Jobs were added if my memory serves, and the game is just... so different now.First, I still recommend it. It's a very new player friendly MMO, and while that annoys me personally, I get the push to make games like this more rewarding to a new player. It's a great experience overall and the story translation is getting better bit by bit. The localization team is also getting a lot better about pushing updates through at a more timely pace - if you knew how long it took to get Season 2, much less the episodes of Season 2 vs Season 3 and then almost immediately Counterattack and Vagrant, you would think the localization team was replaced by gods.So, what changed so much for me to think I need to come back and update a year and a half old review? Everything. Literally everything. When I wrote this review at first, there were six classes, the most recent being Soul... Lord? Master? Edgy Wizard. It was a pretty strong class with few noticable downsides, a stark contrast to the second most recent class at the time - Engineer, which is a class made of downsides and few noticeable postives.Fast forward to now. We were treated to the introduction of a new class - the Card Master. Unleash your inner YuGiOh and throw playing cards at your enemies to destroy the forces of evil... and sometimes capture the forces of evil and use them to destroy the forces of evil! ... So yeah, less like YuGiOh and more like Pokemon. Maybe if the two met. Sounds like it would make a great anime. This class came along with Season 3, which brought tremendous change to the game's basic systems, simplifying almost every aspect of gameplay, and bringing out quite a few gripes from me personally.First and most notably, the weapons system was overhauled. Instead of having unique weapons that you can find from various enemies, each with specific stats to help encourage a particular playstyle, you get two generic classes of weapon - basic, and (S). Only a fool would ever use the basic weapons as they come with no bonus stats, never drop with an option (enchant) on them, and are significantly less powerful than the (S) weapons. Why weapons that aren't (S) weapons exist is well beyond my comprehension, because it doesn't add the same depth of gameplay that, say, having ten different swords to choose from did. Sure - towards endgame, everyone just uses the same powerful weapons from endgame dungeons, but there was a certain charm in seeing lower level players (and sometimes higher leveled players) choose a weapon because of its slightly unorthodox stats.Weapons weren't the only thing - class specific armor was removed entirely until level 180, forcing every class to equip themselves the same and reap generic stamina/strength benefits. It's worth noting that since luck has a semi-unknown effectiveness cap, there's not much point in stacking in, and since only three of now eight classes use magic primarily, it's sensible to just protect mages until level 180, but having to choose what armor you like the best based on the same principle of diversity that weapons once presented just feels better, like you're actually doing something, you know? An even bigger problem (for me personally, your mileage may vary) is how good the generic (S) armor is. They outshine the instance dungeon armor hands down, and protect even the squishiest classes against otherwise challenging boss monsters and huge mobs of enemies. To get the same challenge from low level instance dungeons that newer players would get in Season 1, they'd have to take their armor off entirely. The incredibly powerful weapons would probably still end the fight too fast for the boss to have a fair chance, though.Simplification isn't always bad though. Potions no longer come in health, sp, and combination, and instead only come in combination, and they heal huge. As a Savior main (tremendous HP), HP potions never did anything for me, but now I can get a full heal off of just one potion. Yeah, it's easier than it once was, but it's a welcome change to have potions that heal enough to satisfy every class' needs. Crafting was simplified as well, but it's a bit more double edged - it's easier to gather materials to make weapons, armor, accessories, and food, but crafting has been made generic - no one needs to find a refiner to get them to make cloak kits to take to an accessory crafter and have them make cloaks - you can do it all yourself now. Again, this is just a personal gripe because I prefer slightly more complex systems, and in the end, it really does make crafting a more enjoyable experience. You also level it up by paying in game currency instead of having to craft 10 billion worthless items.As it stands now, you might as well consider yourself new until you hit level 170, and then the game actually starts. The problem now, though, is how much of a sharp increase there is in difficulty past that point. Dungeons go from extremely easy to unfair just like that, and for new players who aren't used to the steady climb in difficulty of Season 1 (and to a lesser extent, Season 2), it seems really sudden. Even to someone like me who's been playing for four years, the endgame dungeons seem poorly balanced to favor players who enchant their gear to get overpowered stats - and honestly these dungeons are all but impossible to complete without overpowered enchants. It seems like a poor choice on the developer's end to balance these dungeons to challenge the players who purposefully made the rest of the game too easy for themselves, instead of balancing the difficulty towards the middle of the road players who were taught by the game that they'll make it if they stay dilligent.Just to provide an example - the first true endgame dungeon is Velfa Library. The boss does almost exclusive magic damage (which most armors and classes do not defend against), but the generic mobs in the dungeon have reasonable HP and while they hit hard, they don't hit super hard. This dungeon is a reasonable challenge, and is balanced well for the level you're supposed to visit it at.Meanwhile, one of the newer dungeons, Road of Dream, is full of generic mobs that hit like a freight train and have health on par with the boss of Velfa Library, each. If you haven't come geared to hit for 100,000 at minimum and/or take thousands of damage per hit, you won't last here for more than a minute. I wouldn't complain about the unreal difficulty if anything in the game up to that point prepared you for it, but nothing comes close. Like I said, you go from "wow that was a great dungeon and a real challenge" in Forgotten Garden, to dead in two hits at Ymir, and you're hard pressed to even level up enough to face these challenges. Ymir becomes available to players at level 190, but at 197 I can't make it past the first room.Oh, and before I forget, let's talk about Wanderer, the eighth class. Soul Man was Edge Magician, so now meet Edge Warrior. A class all about slinging a huge katana everywhere, but wait! The katana is actually a lamp. Like Card Master, this class forgoes the idea of an SP bar, and instead uses something a little different but exactly the same. Also this class is STRONG, like level 50 hitting as hard as a 197 Savior strong. It honestly annoys me to think about how rediculously strong the class is, and although I haven't played it, stats-wise I can't find a downside. I've been in parties with them though, and their average damage output of a few hundred thousand is exactly what the endgame calls for. Now if only they'd balance the rest of the classes like that.Again, I still love this game and recommend it for its gameplay, but when you reach true endgame, it might be your breaking point.

												Let me preface the review by stating that I tend to be extremely thorough when I give feedback to a game. This will be a very long post, but I intend to provide clear, current information about the game so that readers might make an informed decision before committing to a download. Though I may not have put thousands of hours into Latale, I'm an old MMO hand and extremely picky when it comes to games  - the eighty hours of gameplay I've put in were enough to get a character to level 160, create a guild, and otherwise see everything the game has to offer. As such, I have some valid input - I encourage you to read everything I have to say.Please note that the date of this review is Septemeber, 2015. The information provided should only be considered accurate up to this date. Drastic changes have been made to LaTale and more will undoubtedly come. Keep this fact in mind if you find this review at a later date. Tha being said, lets dive on in. CONS:GAME-BREAKING PROBLEMS:-Confusing quests/translations-Content is a year behind the Korean version-Content has been constantly and drastically changed-Content is broken or unfinished in some places -Community is lacking members, support, guides, and information-Gameplay is entirely quest-based and far too easy-Enchanting destroys your items gratuitously, despite the initial "95%" success rate (there are hidden factors that cause items to explode way more than they should - trust me, I did the math)-Crafting is limited, requires a huge initial investment to be able to use, and has depressingly low success ratesMINOR COMPLAINTS:-The sub-class is useless-Sprinting mechanic is clunky-Players don't control passive stat point allocation upon leveling-There are many vestigial items left in the game (items that once were used for crafting, alchemy, or upgrades and currently have no apparent function)-FALSE DIFFICULTY (only time you die is when creatures render you immobile by "chain attacking" as a mob so you can't move, jump, attack... other features like this make it seem unfair to the player and is just frustrating)-Questing becomes unimaginative and repetitive-Certain consumables have extra-long cooldowns when they really shouldn't have one to begin with -Certain classes are clearly better than others (cardmaster) and yet others are clearly pointless to play (poor knights...)PROS:-Casual-100% free to play-There is no pressure or need to spend money on fashion items (which can be bought through NPCs or players with in-game currency)-Devs are generous and frequently give free cash shop items -Small, friendly community-Game economy is stable-Plenty of things to keep you busy after reaching lvl200-Beautiful art, music, and animations-PVP & PVE-Endless quests-Plenty of ways to add passive stats to your character (guilds, dating, item codex, monster images, titles, etc...)-Decent character customization-There is no real way to "ruin" a character build-NO HACKERS, SCAMMERS, OR BOTS-Despite being behind on content, devs seem to still have presence and update semi-regularly-In game achievements -Addictive combo-based fighting-GOOD  PVE equips often FOUND through drops-NostalgicNow, let me explain some points a bit in further detail and then wrap it up. It may seem like there is a lot of bad here, but consider that a  lot of the content issues I have brought up only occur in specific situations. For instance, when I said that some of the content is broken or missing, I am not referring to abundant, general glitchiness. There were a couple situations where broken content clearly inhibited the gameplay. For example, at the water dragon boss - the portal to move to the third instance of the boss fight is broken. I could not continue the fight, so I was not able to finish the quest. This left a bad taste in my mouth because I had to waste a warp capsule and I left the dungeon feeling deprived of potentially awesome content. Things like this frustrate players (especially veteran players who might have nostalgia about that boss).Furthermore, there were several quests that frustrated me because they were confusing. So they ended up cluttering my quest log. Translation was extremely on-point for this game in terms of grammar. Yet, I found myself wanting more clear and detailed explanations for certain dialogues (which may be attributed to the inherent translational errors resulting from language differences). For instance - the sub-class quest! If I hadn't done preliminary research on the topic, I would have ended up freaking out because it seems like your character gets demoted to level 140 and loses all its stats, skills, and equipment. I spent hours looking for resources that just werent there (I had to search forums and piece together little tidbits of info just to figure out what exactly the subclass was). If the quest dialogue had been just a tad more explanative and detailed, I would have known that a specific NPC (available in the Guild Hall *take the town portal*) allows you to change between your main class (which isn't lost) and  your sub class every -thirty minutes- (which is why the sub-class is utterly useless IMO) Yet another quest has you purchase a special warp capsule to enter a mario-themed 8-bit retro world and complete a series of jump quests. The quest dialogue says absolutely NOTHING about that fact. The WORST error I discovered was a quest that told me to hunt "Humbaba 18+" monsters, which don't exsist. However, there exists a "Humbaba 14+." Naturally, I assumed these must be the monsters I needed... Nope. Turns out it was a completely different monster, with a completely different name, that I needed to complete that specific quest. That's the sort of error that makes gamers pull hairs and grind teeth. It was a clear content error, which when considered with all the other minor errors and frustration points, made me feel like I was playing an unfinished product. The fact that the game is free means that I have no real right to complain about recieving a sloppy product. However, there are clear indications that this game was once an MMO giant with tons of features and content. There are vestigial items that indicate crafting was once intricate and involved. You have a mining action, and there are mining spots... but, mining yields no items and has no purpose in the game. There is the option to upgrade your items and add runes, but they don't work or require mining items you will never get. So it's obvious they already had a complete and AWESOME game. What is left is a fragmented ghost of a once amazing and addictive product. Why ruin a good thing? I gave it some thought and I decided that they ultimately changed the game for the better. If the game is involved and hard, it makes it really convenient for people to take advantage by botting, scamming, and hacking... So the community suffers. Additionally, if the game is so hard and involved that players never reach the level cap - there are so many people who will never get to experience the full game. There will be tons of worlds, quests and monsters they will never see because they refuse to hack the hundred-billion ely needed to create the overenchanted equips necessary to fight high level monsters. OGplanet took a stand against that culture and made the gameplay to where you can just kick back with a friend and have FUN. I feel like the changes targeted stressful time wasters like mining because they inhibit progress and encourage a negative community. Now, you don't even need enchants to PVE well... Just good skills. All in all, it's what I was looking for - a relaxing and colorful FREE MMO with friendly people to kill wild boars with :3 It would be better if it was complete and polished, but I can look past it. Hopefully this review provided enough info for you to decide whether you can look past its faults or not for yourself.

												LaTale: 2D platformer MMORPG8/10Having played this game on and off since 2009, I believe I can write a fair review for it.  LaTale is not perfect, but what free to play game is? LaTale has hooked me due to its more in-depth gameplay.Now, a lot of people may have reservations of picking up a free-to-play game, thinking it's pay to win.  This is not the case with LaTale.  Will you need to spend a few bucks to get started, like with an auto looting pet?  Yes.  But here's the nice thing about LaTale: most of the cash shop items are tradeable, so you can get those items by playing the game and trading with other players.If you're looking for a fun, pretty, cute, silly and exciting 2D rpg experience, then LaTale is the game for you!

												I've tried every class available in this game up to at least Lv.20, and have played three up to the first job change (Guardian, Treasure Hunter, and Meister).  I have to disagree with all the glowing reviews of this game. My experience has just been a mindless repetitive grind with little customization outside of appearance.Suppose I'll start with what I mean by "little customization." You earn a single skill point each time you level up. You use these to learn new weapon attacks and passive skills. Every weapon tree, however, only has 4 or 5 attacks that have to be learned in a certain order. There's no branching, no "this or that." Just straight up, "these are your five attacks that you'll use over and over for the rest of your days." All skills, including passive ones, are level-locked also, further limiting your choices of where to spend your points. Further still, some classes only have one weapon type available to them (Soul Breakers, and Engineers of the starting classes).After undergoing my first class change from Knight to Guardian, Engineer to Meister, and Explorer to Treasure Hunter, I noticed that of the three, Guardian and Treasure Hunter play very much the same as their first-tier counterparts. You start off with slightly flashier versions of the same five skills you had previously (in the case of Knight to Guardian, you lose the ability to use any other weapons besides knuckles), and not much else noticably changes. Meister was the only class of the three that played differently in that now instead of swinging around a fashionably metrosexual pumpkin man-purse, I now had a nifty yellow mech as my weapon. Unfortunately with the mech, every attack, even basic attacks, drain your SP. Having low SP to begin with, I was only able to fight one or two enemies before having to rest. Not sure if I was just doing something wrong, but needless to say, I didn't exactly see a whole lot of meisters rolling around.Leveling in LaTale consists of talking to one quest giver, receiving multiple quests to kill certain enemies, completing thosequests, then receiving more quests to kill those same enemies five more times until you move to the next area and repeat the process. It's incredibly tedious and gets very stale quickly.There seems to be some sort of crafting system, but I could never figure out how to participate. It's not included in any of the tutorial quests. Further, equipment and potions drop so frequently, I question just how useful crafting would even be in this game.I have some minor issues with the interface also, such as the inability to increase the font size, and how your tracked quests disappear from your HUD whenever you log out or the game crashes. Again, rather minor.One last thing...prirings are totally and unabashedly a ripoff of porings from RO.

												I have about 5 hours logged onto the game, so this may be pre-emptive, but I'd like to say something about it so far.Likes:- Great artwork!The game itself is beautiful and it feels unique. The world itself is unique and so are the characters. It seems like there is a lot to see in this game.- Music is very enjoyable.Every area has its own music, which tells me that they put A LOT of time and effort into this game. Being a musician myself, I know how much effort goes into 1 piece of music.  All of the music i've encountered so far has a very warm sound to it and sounds very happy. That ties in with the friendly atmosphere of the game.- Friendly environmentLike it advocates, this game has a very friendly atmosphere attached to it, which is extremely desirable for MMOs these days. One of the biggest problems in MMOs is the community in most games. While I wouldn't say that this is an extremely populated game, it does attract friendly people. I've not seen any slander or inappropriate text in all chat and everyone seems to be willing to help out.Dislikes:- Strange Controls:It's nothing you can't get used to, but double-tapping to run gets pretty tedious. The original hotkeys are also sort of strange in comparison to other MMOs. You can set them yourself, but initially, will be a little confusing.- Quest UI:The quest UI is a little strange in that, it has the story description of the quest on the first tab and then another tab for the specific quest description/reward. It's not a terrible feature, but it's not quite convenient either. You always have to click over to see the specifics. A quest bar on the side will pop up also to help you track your quests, but clicking on them doesn't bring up the quest in the quest log, so that's also not very convenient.- Quests are a bit boring:I normally love the grind on MMOs, but it just doesn't seem too fun in this game. You collect a quest to kill certain mobs and then after turning it in, you are asked to kill them again to collect items from them, and sometimes even asked to go back a 3rd time to kill the same mob to get a different quest item. It seems a bit too tedious.- Not much difficulty:It's pretty easy. I guess the first 20 levels of any MMO can be described the same way, but I mean, I didn't really have to try too hard to be good at my class.- Limited Battle Customization:Maybe I was spoiled with WoW, but it seems like the battle customization is pretty low. I've gotten a few new skills and chose where to put my skill points in my own order, but they are still capped by levels. I suppose that's fair, but in terms of having unique skills, you kind of just put the points in your own order, but you're still dictated by the level system. I'm sure this won't be a problem in later levels, but for now, it does make leveling not very fun.All in all, a pretty good game, but I couldn't see myself investing a lot of my time into this game. I'm glad to have gotten the experience so far and will probably grind a bit more just to see if my opinion changes. I wouldn't recommend the game as a long term game, but I would recommend it if you're looking for a friendly place to game,

												0 playtime because I've played this game a lot off steam. Like, more than I'd like to admit. Probably 1000+ hours worth, or somewhere around that number. I was there when the closed beta for both OGP and Aeria games held this little treasure, and I was there when there were just 4 initial classes, and you had to get to 80 to rank up. Back when puzzle pieces were locked behind a paywall.Needless to say, I've played this game a lot. Not so much anymore, what with real-world responsibility weighing down on me, but I can tell you for a fact that this MMO is definitely worth your time.The animations are fluid, and the way combat works is very different from Maple Story, and I believe it looks a thousand times nicer too. Whereas in Maple you'll usually stick to a spot, throw a couple skills out at enemies, jump around to avoid an enemy or something then repeat, Latale has you constantly spamming your rather nice looking skills, stick-then move basis where enemies go down relatively quickly to  your power in a gratifying and enjoyable way. And the game rewards you for your quick movements and your quick attack chains with a hit counter (Which, by the way, increases your exp and ely awards the higher it is).Since it's many updates and balances, Latale has a total of 6 initial classes (since I last checked), the 4 main ones (Warrior, Knight, Wizard, Explorer) splits off into two paths each, while the other two (Engineer, Soul breaker) just change into their own new thing. These changes happen at level 40 (Used to be 80, that being a long and arduous journey to get there), and once you do get to that golden number, just about everything changes. Whatever class you chose to go into at that level gets massive buffs, new skills, sometimes even new playstyles (Like Engineer --> Meister, go from wielding a suitcase into a pilotable mecha. No, nothing in that sentence is a typo.), which radically either changes the game, or sets you on a new course with new skills and powers to try out on the masses of enemies just awaiting to die. And the class upgrades beyond that do just the same.Lately, the game seems to have gotten a pay-to-win vibe to it, which is very discouraging to new players. But most of the items you can buy in the item shop, you can attain in-game through either some work or some of the many events that OGP seems to like to throw it's players. Stuff like the fashion items and the auto-loot pets, along with some other key items that makes life super easy is locked behind that paywall. It's fairly annoying, but the game's entertainment value for what it does and it's wild ride more than makes up for it. Plus, if you do so choose to spend money, you get some relatively good value for what you spend (Take advantage of the sales!).Unfortunately, like almost all MMOs do, it starts to get grindy once you start getting to 70+. Fairly late in the game, and at the point where you've already accomplished so much, and there's much more to go, that you'll either want to keep going, or you'll start to fall out and just play once in a while. I'll leave this particular part up to you to decide if you'd want to keep going from there. But even if you do play up until then, it'll be the best ~70 levels you've ever played in an MMO, I guarantee it.Not gonna lie, there is some pretty bad localization in this. They've had over a few years to get it right, and they still haven't, even some of the NPCs that have been in the game since day 1 of closed beta. If you're a grammar nazi, or if seeing silly sentences turns you off, be warned. There's some story to the game, and unless you have an open mind or you're totally cool with skipping all the dialogue and text boxes on the quests, you'll get annoyed quickly. There's some untranslated items sprinkled around too, though not nearly as common.To sum it all up, Latale is a fantastic ride, with it's combat feeling fresh and exciting with each new skill and class one tries out, and continues to do so until the later levels. While the game is slightly pay-to-win, it's largely negligible unless you want to take a bunch of shortcuts or have that autolooting pet. The localization is at best passable, and at worst downright terrible, but if you can look beyond that, latale is a fantastic MMO to sink your teeth into.And no, it's not a Maple Story clone. IMO, I think Maple could take some lessons from Latale.

												This is one of the best games I've ever seen. While mixing anime with an MMORPG, La Tale was born. This game is one of the best anime MMORPGs on Steam.The game's community is ranged widley from children to young adults. Event gift bundles give way to obtaining cute pets such as the Champion Wannabe Coco pet, a Christmas event reindeer pet.As much as the community varies, I have not once seen any foul language or explicit topics in the chat. Posted: August 31, 2014
												I would like to start by saying that we all have our own preferences when it comes to gaming, so never 100% go off of reviews.Anyway, this game is indeed Free-To-Play. You do not need to spend money in game, as of yet, to progress in the game. However, I instantly fell in love with this game, within the first 3 hours of gameplay, I spent a small bit of money on it. £6 ($10). With this, I managed to get an awesome gothic themed outfit, an adorable pet and some special items which lets me finish my quest without having to speak to the quest-giver. Which I think is fairly reasonable considering other games I've played, the tokens have cost tons more and you can't get nearly as much as this. The basic armour is particularly fashionable and not an eye-sore. The weapons are also considerably badass-looking. I'm currently using a Staff (I'm a Wizard) which I think looks a bit like one of Sailor Moon's weapons.Items are relatively easy to retrieve via looting, however most drops are junk items - the game tells you this in a little note in the item's description. Lag is extremely minimal. I may have d/ced from the server once or twice in the course of 12 hours. The game has multiple channels with about 7 or so servers within each, which really helps the lag spread out and, well, not lag.One thing that people will complain about is that this is a side-scroller. I am telling you now, it feels nothing like one of those. I know that sounds stupid considering it is in fact a side-scroller. But, it just doesn't really feel like one. The graphics are cute and very well done. I applaud the pixel artists and background artists that have put the effort into their job, it really shows. The music as well, extraordinarily beautiful. None of it is a slow, short and painful loop. Which I yet again commend, it never grates on your ears. Going back to the graphics, the attacks are fabulous. I feel as though some attacks aren't pixelated. The fire attacks I currently have don't look pixelated, which adds reality to the game. Some of the animations for the attacks are utterly adorable. For example, 'Bubble Bubble', your character uses a bubble blower to blow some bubbles. And afterwards their eyes go all wide and shiny. I love it. And something similar for 'Ice Spear', I think that's what it's called. The monsters are also very well pixelated, some of the pixelling in this game is gorgeous, and is enough to make you want to play.This game has a combo system which lets you get attacks in quicker. All moves are AOE, apart from your regular attack which makes mobbing all the more easy. I play an RPG where a mage has extremely limited AOE moves, painful I tell you. As you increase the combo, you'll get more exp. Levelling up seems to be easy. I'm already level 30, but the levels do go ridiculously high, I think I've seen a level 192?What I've met of the players, they all seem to be English and friendly. Most higher levels are normally snobbish and frown upon lower levels, but they help you out and treat you as an equal, as it should be in all games.The quests are very generic. Kill this, loot this, talk to this person. Which is one of the downsides to the game. I've already strayed from the quests as it is due to this. But I think most games are like this. Everyone eventually abandons the quests and goes off on their own. I think I've still got a level 3 quest there someone. Along with level 10s, 22s etc. You actually don't need the quests, however they do give you quite a bit of experience and 'Ely'. Which is the game's currency, much like most games is gold.The pets in this game don't attack. The highest level for them seems to be 20. Apparently, which I had to find out from a higher level player because the help guide wasn't much help, the egg hatches at level 5, the pet matures at level 10 and it can change its appearance or something. I can't fully recall. Different pets have different abilities. My current pet can open a shop at level 5 and at level 10 it will increase my magic and luck. When your pet reaches 100% exp, you must go and buy a supplement to level it. There are 4 different supplements which increase in price. Lvl 1-4 which is 10k; Lvl 5-9 which is 30k or so and it increases accordingly. I think it eventually gets to 100k or something ridiculous like that. The first pet you get through a quest is useless, cannot hatch and has no abilities whatsoever. I would say it's there to look pretty, but it doesn't even do that. It's an egg with wings, called 'Handsome Egg'. Utterly useless.To sum it all up, I would strongly recommend this game. But, remember my opening statement - 'I would like to start by saying that we all have our own preferences when it comes to gaming, so never 100% go off of reviews.'

												If you enjoy MMORPG's, this is the game for you.  Don't let the cutesy 2D anime graphics fool you, this game has tons of content that can keep you occupied for hours and hours.  I WILL say that the beginning of this game is quite tedious with the tutorial quest no lie, but after that it gets better as you level.    The thing that stood out in my opinion was the fact that there are so many classes to choose from, some that you would see in a typical mmorpg like Wizard or Warrior, and a few unique classes such as Soul Breaker and Engineer.        Each class also has at most 2 advancements to choose from when you reach level 50, which takes less than a week, don't worry.  Examples of the advancements include Warrior's having a choice of becoming either Warlord, which specializes in the spear or two-handed sword, or Blader, which specializes in dual blades.  Which would you prefer if you were warrior?  Slow, but Powerful?  Or Fast attack speed with damaging combos?  You decide.       I'm only talking about one class here too.  Even after 2nd Job advancements, the game takes it further with 3rd job advancements at lvl 100, then Sub-Class advancements at 140, and finally, the new edition 4th job classes at lvl 190.  Sounds like a long journey right?  It is.  However, with dedication and hard work, you too can gain 3rd job, and even 4th job too!        My highest level so far is Lvl 117, an Engistar (3rd job class Engineer), and im getting there, not giving up till I get that sub class! :)  Don't get me wrong, I don't play this game 24/7, I think of this game as a "pick up and play it for a bit" one.  Sure, you can just go all out and level to the max, but sometimes its best to take it slow, if you know what I mean.        AND, of course, play with your pals too!  The game is enjoyable to its fullest if you have a full party of friends, heck, even strangers, duking it out on the Instance Dungeon bosses with healing support, tanking, and damage dealing as the perfect team comp.      I Would talk more about La Tale, but, I'd just be going on and on xD.  So, with that in mind, see ya guys in game!IGNs on La Tale:  Valioa (lvl 140 Soul Lord),  And SacredBelmont (Lvl 123 Engistar)

												First things first... (I have countless hours in this game being a closed beta player)You will not be using your old accounts with the steam version (Something they will be fixing or figuring out soon [Hopefully]).Second, if you arent in America you will be experiencing lag (It used to be way worse.... even for the American players).Alright so here we go...A lot of people will compare this to many similar games, the one best known will be Maplestory but lets stop right there...This game is what maplestory wish it could have been at its core. It is not pay to win.The community is friendly (90% every commnuity has its jerks).An active staff that listens to its players (Seriously, players have made concerns and had OP items nerfed because they felt an unfair advantage to things that were easier to acquire with cash).90% of everything is tradeable or farmable (non cash items that is, most cash is tradeable or giftable)Hackers... I honestly have never seen them and only heard of them in stories..Broken economy? No sir. Bots? A few spam bots but the game has block features which mute players.Now for a review.In short, You are a hero of the game (Not THE HERO... a hero), a young adventurer making your way in the world trying to figure out what happened to "Iris Livier" and her travelers. The story is in parts and along the way you unlock bits and pieces with semi deep quest lines and story telling (It honestly gets REALLY good towards end game). Like most MMORPGS you will be grinding and leveling. Questing and being challenged by dungeons and bosses (even special Time attack dungeons with bad♥♥♥♥♥music). There's lots of side things to do as well... Develop and perfect your playstyle!PVP!Join a guild. (Harvest guild crops and get to know your community!)Learn a profession.Mine your heart out.Fish forever!Dig! (Yes dig for items in any map that isnt in towns)Dance! (There's a dancing mini game!)Chill out.Be a merchant.And so much more...There's so much more freedom in this game than most other 2d MMORPGS...If you truly enjoy 2D MMORPGS then give this game a shot.. A REAL SHOT...

 La Tale Review	Finally got around to write this review, this game is one of the few MMOs I actually like.Don't judge by my play time here.I've played for years on the OGPlanet Launcher. Story 	The story is rather simplistic.The story is centered around Iris Reviere and her party.She is an explorer with numerous adventures who made a name for herself.But one day, she suddenly disappeared without notice and no one knows where she actually is.She is the person that brings you in the world of La Tale and after that you are left on your own devices as you follow through her footsteps and in the process making it into your very own journey.That's it for the story I guess, there alot more since the story is really big for an MMO but this is just a summary of what you should expect. Gameplay	The gameplay in La Tale is great.The combat especially.It's dynamic, varied and fun.There are plenty of weapons to use depending on your class and each one has alot of combo variety. Some are more focused on supporting fellow party members instead of hitting hard.Some focus on dealing damage with your spells and actives while others focus on raw damage straight from your basic attacks and tankiness.There are alot of classes since every base class can go in 2 directions - either an upgrade of his defeault class or go on a totally different route with a completely new weapon.Forgot to mention.The game can get grindy depending on the class you are usingIf you use Card Master or Wanderer you will have a great experience as they level up extremely fast but with other classes you will level up slower.The game's level capacity is 250 if I am not mistaken. You could probably reach it in a month depending on the time you spent on this game. Graphics	The graphics are gorgeous in my opinion.Cute anime graphics with great pixelated art and particle effects.Attention to detail in artwork is alot and is really appreciated. Customization	Now, customization is really varied... that is if you are willing to pay ofcourse,You can still look unique without really paying but it will require hard work so you can farm enough Ely - the ingame free currency in order to buy Astro items from the market and other people.However 90% of the Astro items are purely cosmetics and do not make you stronger at all.Astro is the premium currency. Community	This game has the friendliest community I've seen in a game.The game advertises is self as the friendliest MMO and it does not lie.Every single person I have met her - I have had great time with them.Telling each other dirty jokes or grinding together while Music	Music is a joy to listen to, every track is beautiful and has it's own atmosphere.The music is the thing that makes La Tale feel like La Tale.It makes the game feel unique. (Despite being similar to MapleStory, lol... but judging how MapleStory is faring these days... you're better off with La Tale instead).

												This game is not that horrible. Its for people who pull up youtube videos while leveling their guy up, not so much for people looking for a rich gameplay and story experience. Not that the gameplay and story is bad, actually its pretty good. Unlike Maplestory where if you just touch an enemy it registers damage, enemies have attack animations. This makes a huge difference because it allows you to dodge the attack and counter. People may think that this does not make such a difference, but it does especially when there is a combo system which rewards you with money and exp for high combos. You even get a light attack, strong attack, jumpings attacks, blocks, and more. However, leveling and killing certain monsters (ones that don't stagger) are much more difficult, but fun. English translations are AWFUL like REALLY ♥♥♥♥ING BAD. Some npcs and items just have random symbols instead of words, however they are few and somewhat far between. Skills are pretty cool looking and interesting, however due to the lack of a LaTale youtube community, you will have to guess on what the skills does based on its description, which is sort of bad due to the translation errors. There is a fashion shop and some items do give you stat bonuses, but the cool thing about this game is that you can actually pay for special points (not cash shop points) using in game money to buy those items for a limited time (however you can keep buying them). Also due to the amazing amount of events and dedicated staff, you can actually get permanent cash shop items and stuff just for free! Now the main downside of this game is the really bad tutorial. They really dont tell you very much and its a lot better to find a high level character and ask him or her for help.All in all, 7/10. Get it if you like to watch youtube videos on the side while doing something somewhat productive.If you say Maplestory is better, this game is much harder and has better staff, but somewhat smaller community.

												I wouldn't recommend ever even trying this. This game has some of the worse controls I've experienced. The normal walk speed is painfully slow. To run, you must double tap an arrow key. Class descriptions in character creation are horribly lacking, so you don't really know what you're picking. The text they use for character names blends into the background, making finding NPCs a chore. Gameplay is pretty bland, though the possibility of comboing moves is there - so at least you have to mash more than one button to win. Quests are the typical kill x and collect y.HOW MANY TIMES DO I HAVE TO GET STUCK ON A ROPE FOR IT TO WORK PROPERLY? I swear, every other time I climb up a rope I go past the top of it slightly and get stuck in a looping climb animation until I go back down the rope a bit, then back up. This ruins game flow horribly. Combine this with the running issue described above and it just feels horrible.

Posted: June 1, 2015
												I wanted to like this game because I usually like 2D MMOs, but this game is just unplayable.The first issue is the terrible translation. It's so bad that I can't understand the storyline at all, so I just skipped it. The tutorial questgivers are equally as bad but at least you can understand what they say, simple instructions after all. It's a shame that the initial questgiver doesn't tell you how to dash before instructing you to do so, becuase I spent forever scouring the menus to find which key you use to dash. Eventually I found it in the skills menu, and it said "double tap directional arrows"... Would that have been so hard to put into the quest dialogue?I ran on a little further and it turned out this very instruction was on a signpost... But I had to navigate away from the questgiver to see that, so i'd only have known that if i'd given up on the quest already...Then it turned out that the person I handed the quest into was NOT the same person I got it from, but the game never told me that, so straight away I feel like i'm having to contort my brain to the game's logic. If I had known that the quest's end was to my right I would have ran on and expected more instruction, but as it was I was attempting to dash in place near the questgiver before having any idea how to do so. Did they even playtest this?One thing I noticed at this point is that my actions are delayed. I start holding the right arrow and only start moving a second later, and then once i've let go of the key, my character jumps forwards a few feet to where I would have been had the game responded in time when I first pressed the key. It's clear that these guys have no idea how to make an online game. Keep my movements smooth clientside, and upload them to the server. Instead what we have here is an unresponsive mess that keeps making me jump about to compensate for the lag.I attempted to set up an Xbox controller but the remapping tool made no sense, and required that you already knew the keyboard controls fully.The game only works in two resolutions, and for some reason the widescreen resolution will not work in full screen. Borderless in available, but it just floats in a tiny box in the middle of my monitor so what's the point? You can't even just maximise the window.The game doesn't explain it's skills system very well, and trying to get to grips with the combat proved frustrating, as did attempting to climb ladders and dodge enemies.Basically this game leaves a terrible first impression. So bad in fact that I don't think i'll be playing any more of it. Bad english, bad controls, bad lag, bad interface... Basically there's nothing worthwhile here.

												La Tale is really cute and really fun at first, but it has a few major flaws.First of all, the combat is quite entertaining. All of the abilities and attacks look appealing and feel satisfying to use.Customization is limited, but you can still come up with something super kawaii.The player base feels small, but you can still find people and likely make a few friends to queue up with for dungeons.I've never actually completed a dungeon, however, since I could not find the appropriate number of people; therefore, I can't talk about that much. What I can say, though, is that they are challenging and likely equivalent to your typical WoW dungeon.But now flaws...First of all, there's this whole "you can only keep this item for x days" thing which is kinda disappointing when the item is a good weapon that you were given for completing a quest.Speaking of which, quests are repetitive fetch quests and are the exact same in each zone. Collect special drops from x, y, and z monsters twice, rinse, repeat.The game is also rather glitchy in that some text is buggy like once I had a staff that basically had glitchy text as it's name. There are also minor things indicating poor translation or a lack of polish like when your character shouts, "Icicle Fear" when casting Icicle Spear.Worst of all is that nothing is ever really clear. For instance, you might pick up an item saying that it does nothing when it is actually pretty important or is used in crafting. But you wouldn't know that until you just randomly discover it since there's no information online.Lastly, I got some random virus which only appeared after downloading the game and disappeared after uninstalling, so players beware.The game is fun, but if you're looking for a fun, anime RPG, maybe look elsewhere since this is honestly one in a thousand. 5.5/10(Minus a few extra points for virus if you want)

If you're in South America, don't even play this game. Otherwise, consider it.+ Nice concept+ Nice classes+ Less 'gayer' More manlier than other side-scroller games- Awful customization- Weird buttons- Lag! Delay! Lots of!- You can't play with your official OGPlanet accountPROS1. Very good conceptThe game itself has a nice concept. It's a sidescroller RPG just like MapleStory, Wonderking or WindSlayer (I think that's the name, lol), which means that although some monsters are strong you can regroup better on platforms and hit them better without having to look your back. That's fun and it's basically the concept I liked most. I'm not saying that non-platform games are better or worse, no, that's just my personal opinion.2. Nice classesThe game today has nice classes. About to five classes with small subdivisions between them (for example my class is an explorer but I follow the archer skill-tree pathway or I'm a knight that uses the shield, etc). It's waaaay better than Tibia some games that have about to three classes or MapleStory other games that have about to 31! This game classes amount is... enough.3. Nice visualThis game has a nice outfit if compared to other side scrollers. At most of them your head is quite big and disproporcional if related to your body and it looks like you're a child and the only difference between male and female characters are the hair (in some other games the female characters don't even have breasts). LaTale got a point in topic 3, characters seem more normal, less bizarre. I know that look like a useless topic but it's not, sometimes the game has to prove itself that it's worthy to play, even with those "useless" outfits.CONS4. Weird sprites Your character is awful customizable. You have about to 7 options of picking your hair, 4 options for your skin and so on. That's not bad if looked that way but sometimes in cities you face layers with extremely bizarre combination of sets. I know, it's their lives, not mine -- I know, but seeing that only makes me think that the developers are making all effort to earn money in all possible way. FFS I've seen a girl with a following shadow-skull beneath her, other time I saw a guy with a bigger than him sword. Maybe I'm too rigid with those things in games or maybe I'm right.5. Weird buttonsThe buttons are somehow weird. You pick items up with the V button, in the bottom middle of the keyboard, making yourself get messed up sometimes and you don't pick it all! Neverthless when it's only one (ONE, I repeat) item laying in the ground a pop-up opens and it shows the SINGLE item and the options to pick it or not. Jeez, if I pushed V I want to pick it, no more asking, ok?6. DelaaayThis one made me sad. It was the only negative aspect of this game that didn't allow me to play normally. Although I've listed about two other negative aspects, I could play the game with them with no problem at all since the game's not that bad and it seems quite funny. Those problems were minimal. But the delay for me (I live in Brazil with a 15 Mbps connexion) was incredibly huge, very huge. Way to huge (no, really, huge). The delay was so big in a manner that I couldn't farm level 1 monsters precisely, I had about to 1500 ms ping! My character jumped right after the jump button was already released and I attacked right after I released the button too! OGPlanet probably has a plausible reason for allowing brazilian players play with so much delay but that's not the point. Delay is tolerable until a point (around 250 ms average) but, really, I can't play. There's no way to gather friends or a party to fight a boss if it takes more than one second for the controllers to respond. Sometimes it lagged too. It's sad to see a game with such potencial not being played due to delay. If OGP fixes this issue I promise I remove this ngative review but by this point I feel like I have a moral obbligation to warn anyone who reads this. Thank you for your reading.7. The needing of creating another accountThis topic is somehow related to topic 6. I played LaTale in 2012 because I wanted to try the game and I had the same lag and delay problem. Okay, I quit and today -2014- I saw there was LaTale here on Steam and I downloaded it since it was free to play. But when I pressed play it said I couldn't because there was another account with my name and another e-mail registered as mine. WTF, that's MY account, I'm not hacking or stealing anything from anyone, I'm just accesing MY account. But I couldn't, I had to create a different nick and create a new e-mail to register the account to. Was it really necessary?

												As a big fan of maplestory, I can say this game can be the spiritual successor to it. It has fantastic rpg elements with loads of options and stuff that can keep you busy for days (but i aint got no time for that anyway), this game is a must play. the fact that a free to play rpg is not a pay to win just keeps my day shining.+great gameplay+impressive pixel art+unique classes that change gameplay styles+alot of unnecessary but cool options (ex: a pet automatically picking items for you, enchanting your pet to give you permanent bonuses)however the only complaints i have are these two:-weird design descisions (for example, when you start the game it tells you to jump over a small area, it says ABOVE that small area how to jump, but i couldn't see that sign when i was still behind the rock.)-the game doesn't help you understand alot of things (for example, there is a stat called "luck" at the start of the game that changes based on your class, the game doesn't say the effects of that stat (the effect i didn't know was that luck increases money earned from monsters), another example is that i didn't know the difference between stamina (which i assumed was the SP bar), and magic (which i also assumed was the SP bar???). this is also a weird design descision.eitherway good or bad i highly recommend this game, as a free to play you should have nothing stopping you from trying this mmorpg out. this is my favorite 2D mmo and i am very impressed by its mechanics. though some things are stopping this game from being the best.8.5/10

												Edit: (03/03/16) The latency has become a horrible problem and is starting to hinder the ability to play. I have played this game off and on for years now with long periods of down time. I loved the structure of the game, but the implementation of the way it all worked had always felt wrong or slightly off. Getting back into the game, things feel smoother and as they should be. The classes are still flashy and fun to play, and I see some skill animation changes have come around too which is really nice. 												I do recommend this game, BUT there's some things that are bad.First off, the good things. It's easy to level up in this game. Also, in order to get at least some decent looking items, you have to do surveys and receive tokens which are only 1 per "quiz". you need at least 30 for a top or bottom using these tokens too. So, I don't suggest wasting your money on the clothing options, just use the free money to get armor or weapons. Other than that, this game is sort of like Maple Story. 												La Tale is a simple side-scrolling game most comparable to Maplestory back in its younger years. You start out by picking one of the classic RPG classes, which then can be advanced into an even better class at level 80. The quests are simple; kill 'x' amount of monsters or get this item from so-and-so or go to this NPC. It isn't that difficult to level up in, and the storyline is easy to understand despite the grammar lost in translation. Despite the massive amount of grinding done, it isn't that painful and the game makes it relaxing. The quirky yet colorful graphics are anime/manga-like, and the colors for equipment and such aren't gender restricted. I highly reccomend that everyone reading this review should try the game for at least five to ten minutes; even if it's not your cup of tea.

												  After around an hour's worth of play, La Tale puts a lot of interesting elements on the table, makes questing easy and in no way frusterating, has great music, and makes me sad that MegaMan Online was cancelled.  I'll continue.  La Tale is a 2D side-scrolling MMORPG by Actoz Soft, a rather unknown company.  The first aspect that La Tale does right is not losing the player's attention in the first five minutes.  Many MMO's start out with some lame backstory, a bunch of tutorials, and a year's worth of starter quests before you even get into the actual game.  La Tale gives you a tutorial, some quests, and throws you in.  No bull.  And I like that.  Gameplay is divided into combat and platforming.  Platforming isn't too difficult, but adds a much needed twist in the enviroments.  La Tale's UI is not a cluster-eff, and isn't confusing.  The art style is sweet, very anime-like, and I'm fine with that.  Controls will take getting used to, but there not too hard to learn.  The music in La Tale is amazingly good, it sounds like some of Capcom's retro tracks, and some of Sonic CD's lesser known hits, but also sounds like it's own style.  It is very rhythmic, and Ireally enjoyed listening to it.  At the end of the day, La Tale is a breakaway from the traditional MMO setup, and it's really good.  I'm sad that MegaMan Online was never created because of how great this game is.  Even if you can't into traditional MMO's, you should at least try this one.  It's a nice change of pace in a saturated market.

												Now I've played a few MMOs in my life and this isn't the worst. But it isn't the best. it's just sort of decent. I see the inspiration it took from Maplestory but even then that MMO only really appeals to a very niche audience, as does this game. Well let's get into the aspects of this game.The plot, and don't tell me "Oh, it's an MMO plot doesn't matter" because it does, Tera has a good plot and that's an MMO.  The plot is pretty basic, go here, help this npc to stop some big evil force and she's with you as a sort of Navi character. It's decent story but they actually give you the choice to skip the plot, which is a bad idea. I understand it's independently developed but I would rather a slightly mediocre voice over, over just text. And they put some of these text dumps right in the middle of enemy territory, which gets to be annoying.Now with the gameplay. It's repetitive. So it Tera's, but they at least constantly throw new abilities at you and get you to learn them. And each class plays drastically different from the next. You can pretty much put these classes into three categories. Melee Martial, Ranged Martial, and Magical. And each class within those categories plays the exact same. They advertise over 40 unique classes but they fail to produce much diversity in their gameplay. Not to mention that they just hand you weapons that are decently powerful, it isn't until the first boss that you get a more powerful weapon. The game pretty much holds your hand throughout the experience. I also had a lot of lag and even had the game crash on me during a transition. The only good thing I can say about the gameplay is the respawn function this game has, where you can either decide to respawn in town or in the field.The soundtrack is average. It's soothing, I guess that's a good thing.And now, onto the aesthetics. This game has the same chibi anime appeal that Maplestory has. While at the same time you have to play the game windowed in a decently small window, this makes the game itself harder on the eyes, at least for me, and once you get to Elias there are just too many people around and it was really a strain on my eyes to look at the surroundings. The enemies aren't threatening either, even Hyperdemension Neptunia had that problem but at the same time they did have some threatening boss enemies. Even the first boss in this game looks adorable.Age Rating: E for Cartoon ViolenceOverall Rating: 4/10So in the end I wouldn't suggest it for most of the gaming community, so it will not get a recommendation from me. Instead I'm going to recommend it to you if you enjoyed Maplestory or Gaia Online. I couldn't suggest this game to most of my friends so I won't recommend it here.

												Edit: (03/03/16) The latency has become a horrible problem and is starting to hinder the ability to play. I have played this game off and on for years now with long periods of down time. I loved the structure of the game, but the implementation of the way it all worked had always felt wrong or slightly off. Getting back into the game, things feel smoother and as they should be. Maps flow excellently now, quests are considerably easier to understand, leveling up is not a total chore right from the get-go, making money isn't an exhausting issue, many things seem to be in nice places with more proper labels. Compared to what the game is now, LaTale felt much, much more unorganized when I last played. The classes are still flashy and fun to play, and I see some skill animation changes have come around too which is really nice. (Warrior's heavy attack is not some clunky slow swing now)All in all, LaTale is getting to a point where it honestly should have been at a long time. But hey, better late than never. Give this game a shot if you enjoy(ed) Maplestory.Edit: Okay, I do see what other people mean about the translations being poor. They definitely need to be revised for proper English. It looks like some Asian kids with a terrible understanding of English wrote more than half of the scripts for the NPC's. One character even says something in a different language but spelled with English letters. That's just...massively stupid... I believe that's called Singlish? idk, needs to be fixed.

												edit: ignore my play-time on here, I play the non-steam version and have over 5,000 hours of playtime.This game has one of the best communities of any MMO I've played, (I've beta-tested over 50 MMOs and played 30-50 others).The gameplay is smooth and the servers are pretty much lag-free.The combat is very action-based but not so much that you need fast reflexes (for most content anyway).The grinding speed has been gradually increased since release with the new end-game grind (lvl 200-220) being incredibly slow, not much content is locked behind lvl 201+ though, this gives more of a sense of value to the end-game lvls despite them not unlocking much.The cash shop is very fair, there are basically no items that give stats/advantages that aren't available (in bulk) through normal gameplay, the game economy generally allows players to easily get into buying and selling cash items for in-game money if they wanted to.The game doesn't appear dated despite being around 10 years old.9/10
